alerts.message:
...The Flash Flood Warning remains in effect until 430 PM MST for
eastern Pima County...

At 221 PM MST...Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated 
that moderate to locally heavy rain was falling in the Catalina and 
Rincon areas as well as Redington pass and Tanque Verde. Over 3 
inches have fallen in some locations.

This includes the following streams and drainages...Tanque Verde 
wash...Rincon creek...Agua Caliente wash...Turkey Creek...Buehman 
Canyon...Deer Creek...Bear Creek...Paige creek and Chimney Rock 
creek.

Precautionary/preparedness actions...

Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of washes 
and streams...roads...as well as other drainage areas and low lying 
spots.

Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where 
you are relative to streams...rivers...or washes which can become 
killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid washes... 
streams or canyons.


Lat...Lon 3240 11047 3213 11049 3220 11064 3238 11073


Meyer



1210 PM MST Mon Sep 21 2015

The National Weather Service in Tucson has issued a

* Flash Flood Warning for...
 north central Santa Cruz County in southeastern Arizona...
 southeastern Pima County in southeastern Arizona...

* until 315 PM MST

* at 1209 PM MST...Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated 
 heavy rain falling over Madera Canyon and Florida Canyon in the 
 Santa Rita Mountains. The rain will continue. Up to two inches of 
 rain have already fallen. Flash flooding is expected to begin 
 shortly.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
 Madera Canyon and western Sonoita. 

This includes the following streams and drainages...Josephine 
Canyon...Box Canyon Wash...Gardner Canyon and Sonoita creek.

Precautionary/preparedness actions...

Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of washes
and streams...roads...as well as other drainage areas and low lying
spots.

Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where 
you are relative to streams...rivers...or washes which can become 
killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid washes... 
streams or canyons.


Lat...Lon 3178 11073 3165 11072 3165 11098 3180 11096


Meyer

alerts.description: Areal Flood Advisory, Flash Flood Watch
alerts.message:
The National Weather Service in Tucson has issued a

* Urban and Small Stream Flood Advisory for poor drainage areas
 for...
 northeastern Pima County in southeastern Arizona...

* until 330 PM MST

* at 133 PM MST...Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated 
 between 0.50 and 1.25 inches of widespread rainfall has occurred 
 across the Tucson Metro area.Although this rain has occurred over 
 several hours...significant ponding of water in roadway dips and 
 other low lying areas is expected. Minor flooding of small washes 
 is likely. 

Precautionary/preparedness actions...

Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause ponding of water in
urban areas...highways...streets and underpasses as well as other
poor drainage areas and low lying spots. Expect heavy flow in
normally dry washes. Do not attempt to travel across flooded roads.


Lat...Lon 3249 11078 3219 11065 3195 11061 3194 11121
 3248 11133




1233 PM MST Mon Sep 21 2015

The National Weather Service in Tucson has issued a

* Urban and Small Stream Flood Advisory for...
 southeastern Pinal County in southeastern Arizona...
 northeastern Pima County in southeastern Arizona...

* until 430 PM MST

* at 1229 PM MST...Doppler radar and automated gauges indicated 1 to 
 1.5 inches of rain in the Catalina mountains including Summerhaven 
 and Mt Lemmon. This will cause small stream flooding in areas 
 around the Catalina mountains including Sabino Canyon and some 
 foothills locations.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
 Mount Lemmon/Summerhaven...Seven Falls...Sabino Canyon...Catalina
 Foothills and Catalina.

Precautionary/preparedness actions...

Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding of washes 
and streams...as well as some roads. Do not attempt to travel across 
flooded roads. Find alternate routes.


Lat...Lon 3254 11054 3238 11048 3229 11093 3251 11088


Meyer


240 am MST Mon Sep 21 2015

...Flash Flood Watch remains in effect through Tuesday
afternoon...

The Flash Flood Watch continues for

* a portion of Southeast Arizona...including the following 
 Baboquivari Mountains...Catalina ...and Rincon Mountains... 
 Dragoon and mule and huachuca and Santa Rita Mountains... 
 galiuro and Pinaleno Mountains...south central Pinal County... 
 southeast Pinal County...tohono o'odham nation...Tucson Metro 
 area...upper Gila River valley...upper San Pedro River 
 Valley...upper Santa Cruz River Valley/Altar Valley...western 
 Pima County and White Mountains of Graham and Greenlee 
 counties. 

* Through Tuesday afternoon

* deep moisture will move across Southeast Arizona into Tuesday
 ahead of a low pressure system west of the area. Rainfall will
 increase especially from the Tucson Metro southward to the
 international border this morning. The coverage and intensity of
 rainfall will then spread northward later today. Scattered
 showers and thunderstorms will continue late tonight into
 Tuesday. Storm total rainfall amounts are expected to range
 between 1 and 2 inches in lower elevations...with amounts in
 excess of 3 inches possible in some mountain locations.

* Several features aloft in combination with ample moisture are
 expected to produce heavier rainfall amounts compared to the
 rainfall that occurred from moisture associated with tropical
 system Linda earlier this month. Please keep this excessive
 rainfall and flood potential threat in mind.

Precautionary/preparedness actions...

A Flash Flood Watch means that conditions are becoming favorable
for widespread flash flooding to develop. Monitor forecasts
closely and be ready to take quick action if flash flood warnings
are issued.

Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize
the dangers of flash floods. If flash flooding is observed...act
quickly. Turn around and take another Route.

Listen to NOAA Weather Radio...commercial radio or television
stations...or your cable television provider for updates on this
flash flood threat.
